content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Joshua Lawson: I was born and raised in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, in a tight-knit neighborhood on the outskirts of the city. My parents were both well-educated—my father has a bachelor's degree in business, and my mother has a graduate degree in education. We lived a comfortable life, with both of my parents working full-time, which allowed me to have access to good schools and extracurricular activities. I was a pretty quiet kid, more interested in reading and spending time with friends than in sports or other typical teenage stuff. I graduated high school a few years ago, but I didn't go to college right away. Instead, I took some time to figure out what I wanted to do with my life. Right now, I'm helping out at home while I explore my options, and I'm trying to stay involved in my community through volunteer work and local activism. I've always leaned left politically, and being a strong Democrat feels natural to me—it's about fighting for equality, education, and making sure people have the opportunities I had.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Joshua Lawson: There was definitely a crossroads moment for me, though it wasn't as dramatic as some people might imagine. I was about 19, right after high school, and I had a few options in front of me. I could have gone to community college, taken a gap year, or even tried to get a job in the city. I was feeling a bit lost, honestly—like I didn't want to just follow the traditional path of going straight to college, but I also didn't want to feel like I was wasting time. I ended up taking a part-time job at a local nonprofit that worked with youth education programs. That experience was eye-opening. I saw firsthand how many kids in my neighborhood didn't have the same opportunities I did, and it made me realize how much I wanted to be part of something bigger. It also made me question whether I wanted to go to college at all, or if I wanted to find a way to make a difference without a degree. In the end, I decided to take a gap year, work with the nonprofit, and explore my interests more. That time helped me grow a lot, and it ultimately led me to where I am today—still figuring things out, but with a clearer sense of purpose.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Joshua Lawson: I think it was a mix of both, honestly. There was a conscious choice to step back and reflect, but a lot of it also just happened as I got involved with the nonprofit. I didn't set out to change my path, but the people I met and the work I did started shaping my perspective in ways I hadn't anticipated. I remember one kid I worked with—his family was struggling, and he was really bright but didn't have the resources to pursue higher education. That moment stuck with me. It wasn't just about making a decision; it was about realizing that my actions could have an impact, even if I wasn't sure what that impact would be. I think that's when I stopped trying to force a direction and started letting the experiences guide me instead.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Joshua Lawson: Absolutely, I think having someone or an organization that could offer guidance or support during that time would have made a huge difference. I remember feeling pretty isolated in my decision-making process, like I was trying to figure everything out on my own. If there had been a mentor or a community program that could have helped me explore my options more thoughtfully, I think I might have felt less pressure to make the 'right' choice right away. The nonprofit I worked with was great, but it was more about the work than the support. I wish there had been more resources for young people in my neighborhood who were trying to navigate their futures without a clear path. It's something I've started thinking about more as I've gotten involved in local activism—how we can create more support systems for kids who are in similar situations to me.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Joshua Lawson: Right now, I don't have a partner or children. My family is my parents and my two younger siblings—my sister is in her second year of college, studying environmental science, and my brother is still in high school, though he's already showing a lot of promise in the arts. My parents are still very involved in my life, even though I'm not living under their roof anymore. They've always been supportive of my decisions, even when I wasn't sure what I was doing. I think that's one of the reasons I feel comfortable being so open about my political views and my desire to make a difference. My family has always encouraged me to think critically and to stand up for what I believe in, which is something I really appreciate. I don't know if I'll ever have a partner or kids of my own, but I know my family will always be a big part of my life.

Going through those interview questions brought back a lot of memories and made me reflect on how far I've come. Talking about my life from the beginning to now reminded me of the comfort and stability my family provided, which shaped who I am today. The crossroads moment at 19 was a turning point, even if it wasn't as dramatic as I once thought. It was the time I started to understand the importance of community and the impact one person can have, especially in a neighborhood where opportunities aren't always equal. I realize now that my journey wasn't just about making a decision—it was about being open to experiences and letting them guide me. I also think about how much support I wish I had back then, not just from a nonprofit but from a structured system that helps young people like me navigate their futures. And even though I don't have a partner or children yet, my family remains a constant source of strength and encouragement, which I'm incredibly grateful for. These reflections have made me more determined to give back and create the kind of support system I wish I had when I was younger.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Joshua Lawson: My grandparents on my mother's side live in Pittsburgh, and they've been a big part of my life growing up. My grandmother, in particular, has always been a source of wisdom and strength. She's retired now, but she used to work as a nurse, and she's always had a way of making you feel seen and heard. I remember spending a lot of time with her when I was younger, especially during the summers. She taught me how to cook, how to garden, and how to really listen to people. My grandfather passed away a few years ago, but I still think about him often. He was a quiet man, but he had a way of making you feel like you were the most important person in the room. My relationship with my grandparents is more about respect and gratitude than anything else. They've always supported my parents, and by extension, me. Even though I don't see them as often as I'd like, I know they're always in my corner.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Joshua Lawson: Outside of my family, there are a few friends who have been really important to me, especially during the time I was working with the nonprofit. One of them, Marcus, was someone I met through the program, and we ended up becoming really close. He's a few years older than me, and he had already been through a lot of the same struggles I was facing. He became like a brother to me, and he helped me see things in a different light. He encouraged me to keep pushing forward, even when I felt stuck. I also have a few friends from high school who I still keep in touch with—some of them went to college, others took different paths, but we all stayed connected. I think having people who understand where you're coming from is really important, especially when you're trying to figure out your place in the world. I don't know where life will take me next, but I know I'm lucky to have people in my life who support me and challenge me to be better.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Joshua Lawson: I live in a neighborhood in Philadelphia that's a mix of old and new—some historic row houses sitting next to newer apartment buildings. It's a pretty diverse area, with a lot of young professionals moving in alongside long-time residents. I like that it's not too far from the city center, so I can still get involved in local events and activism without feeling too removed from the community. There's a small park nearby where I often go to read or just clear my head, and a few cafes that have become my go-to spots for coffee and conversation. The neighborhood has its challenges, like with gentrification and rising rents, but there's also a strong sense of community here. I've met a lot of people through local meetings and volunteer work, and I think that's one of the reasons I feel so connected to the area. It's not perfect, but it's a place where I can still make a difference, and that means a lot to me.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Joshua Lawson: I feel pretty safe here, honestly. There's a sense of community that makes a big difference. I know a lot of the neighbors, and there's always someone around if you need help or just want to chat. That said, there are parts of the neighborhood where things can get a little rough, especially late at night. I've learned to be mindful of where I go and who I'm with, just like most people in the city. But overall, I think the support system here—whether it's through local organizations, friends, or even just the people who live on the same block—makes it a place where I can feel secure. It's not perfect, but it's home, and I'm trying to be part of making it better for everyone.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Joshua Lawson: Living here has been a mix of challenges and rewards. On one hand, I love the energy of the neighborhood—the way it feels like everyone's working toward something, even if it's not always clear what that something is. There's a lot of potential here, and I see it every day in the people who are trying to make things better, whether it's through small acts of kindness or bigger efforts like organizing community clean-ups or advocating for affordable housing. But it's also been tough at times, especially when I see how quickly things can change. I've watched some of my neighbors get priced out because of rising rents, and it's heartbreaking. I know that's part of a bigger issue with gentrification, and it's something I've started to get more involved with—trying to support local initiatives that help keep the community strong. It's not always easy, but I feel like I'm in the right place to make a difference, and that gives me a sense of purpose.

Going through the interview questions about my family, neighborhood, and sense of safety brought up a lot of feelings I hadn't really stopped to think about. Talking about my family reminded me of how much they've shaped who I am—especially my parents and grandparents, who've always encouraged me to think critically and stand up for what I believe in. It also made me realize how lucky I am to have such a strong support system, even as I navigate this uncertain time in my life. When I talked about my neighborhood, it made me reflect on the balance between the challenges we face and the strength of the community here. I know there are issues like gentrification and rising rents that make things difficult for some people, but I also see so much potential and resilience in the people around me. I feel safe here, not just because of the physical environment, but because of the connections I've made with neighbors, friends, and local organizations. It's a place where I can still make a difference, and that gives me a sense of purpose. I think these reflections have made me more determined to stay involved and give back, not just to my neighborhood, but to the next generation of young people who might be going through similar things I did.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Joshua Lawson: A typical week for me is pretty varied, honestly. Some days I'm up early helping out at the local community center, running after-school programs for kids or organizing workshops on civic engagement. Other days, I might spend the morning reading or writing—whether it's for a blog I started about social justice issues or just journaling to process my thoughts. I also try to make time for volunteering with a few different organizations, like a food pantry and a youth mentorship group. On the weekends, I like to take long walks through the park or meet up with friends for coffee or a casual meal. I've found that having a mix of structured work, personal reflection, and social time helps me stay grounded. It's not always easy balancing everything, but I think it's important to keep moving forward, even if it's one step at a time.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Joshua Lawson: I work part-time at a local community center, mostly in the afternoons and evenings, helping with youth programs and administrative tasks. It's not a traditional 9-to-5 job, but it gives me the flexibility to also volunteer with other organizations and stay involved in my neighborhood. I also do some freelance writing on the side—mostly for local blogs or activist groups—when I have the time. It's not always steady work, but I like the variety and the fact that I can use my voice to support causes I care about. I think the part-time nature of my work allows me to stay connected to the community while still having the freedom to explore different interests and figure out what I want to do long-term.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Joshua Lawson: Outside of work and volunteering, I also have a few personal routines that help me stay balanced. I try to wake up early most days, usually around 7 a.m., and spend the first hour of my day reading or meditating. It's a small habit, but it helps me start the day with a sense of calm. I also make it a point to cook most of my meals at home, even if it's just something simple like a stir-fry or a sandwich. I think cooking is a way to take care of myself, especially when I'm juggling so many different responsibilities. I also have a weekly routine of checking in with my siblings and parents, even if it's just a quick call or a text. It's important to me to stay connected with them, especially since I'm not living at home anymore. And on the weekends, I try to set aside time for something I enjoy—whether it's listening to music, going for a run, or just sitting on the porch and watching the neighborhood come to life. It's those little things that keep me grounded and remind me why I'm doing all of this in the first place.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Joshua Lawson: One of the more recent changes to my daily routine has been incorporating more structured time for self-reflection and goal-setting. I started using a journal more consistently, especially after a conversation with a friend who's a counselor. She suggested that writing down my thoughts and setting small, achievable goals could help me stay focused on my long-term vision. So now, I dedicate about 30 minutes each morning after my meditation to journaling—sometimes it's just stream-of-consciousness, other times it's more about tracking my progress or brainstorming ideas for projects I want to work on. It's been helpful in keeping me grounded, especially with everything going on in the neighborhood and with my work. I also started setting aside specific times each week to review what I've accomplished and what I want to prioritize next. It's a small shift, but it's made a noticeable difference in how I approach my days.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Joshua Lawson: I don't have children of my own yet, but I've spent a lot of time observing the routines of kids in my neighborhood and the ones I work with at the community center. A typical weekday for them during the school year starts with getting up early, usually around 7 or 8 a.m., followed by breakfast and getting ready for school. Most of them ride the bus or walk to school, and they're usually back by 3 or 3:30 p.m. After school, many of them come to the community center for after-school programs—some for homework help, others for art classes, sports, or tutoring. I've seen how important those programs are, especially for kids who don't have a lot of structure at home. It's amazing how much they can accomplish in a few hours, and it's one of the reasons I keep doing this work. I think if I ever have children of my own, I'd want to make sure they have access to the same kind of support and opportunities that I had, even if I didn't always realize how lucky I was at the time.

Going through the interview questions from 11 to 15 made me reflect on how deeply my family, neighborhood, and daily routines shape who I am and how I see the world. Talking about my family reminded me of the strong foundation they've given me—especially my parents and grandparents, who've always encouraged me to think critically and stand up for what I believe in. It also made me realize how lucky I am to have such a support system, even as I navigate this uncertain time in my life. When I talked about my neighborhood, it made me think about the balance between the challenges we face and the strength of the community here. I know there are issues like gentrification and rising rents that make things difficult for some people, but I also see so much potential and resilience in the people around me. I feel safe here, not just because of the physical environment, but because of the connections I've made with neighbors, friends, and local organizations. It's a place where I can still make a difference, and that gives me a sense of purpose. Reflecting on my daily routines also made me realize how important it is to find balance—between work, volunteering, personal reflection, and time with loved ones. I've started incorporating more structured time for self-reflection and goal-setting, which has helped me stay grounded and focused on my long-term vision. These reflections have made me more determined to stay involved and give back, not just to my neighborhood, but to the next generation of young people who might be going through similar things I did.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Joshua Lawson: In terms of my health, I'd say I'm generally in pretty good shape, though I've definitely had my share of ups and downs. I used to be pretty sedentary when I was younger, especially during high school, when I spent a lot of time reading or just hanging out with friends. But over the past few years, I've made an effort to be more active. I started going for regular walks, especially in the park near my house, which has helped me stay grounded and clear my mind. I also try to eat as healthily as I can, even if it's not always perfect—mostly because I've learned how important it is to take care of yourself when you're juggling so many responsibilities. I've had a few minor health issues over the years, like occasional stress-related headaches or sleep problems, but nothing too serious. I've started paying more attention to my mental health too, partly because of the work I do with kids and the emotional weight that can come with it. I've been seeing a counselor occasionally, and I've found that talking through things helps a lot. Overall, I'd say I'm in a good place, but I know there's always room for improvement. It's something I'm still learning about, just like everything else in life.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Joshua Lawson: For me, staying healthy is a mix of what makes it easy and what makes it hard. On the easy side, I find that being in nature—like walking in the park or just sitting on the porch and watching the neighborhood—helps me feel grounded and relaxed. It's those moments of stillness that remind me why I'm doing all of this. I also really enjoy cooking at home, even if it's just something simple, because it gives me a sense of control and care over my body. But on the harder side, it's the unpredictability of my schedule. Some days I'm running from one meeting to another, or I'm helping out with a program that runs late, and that can make it tough to stick to a regular routine. I also struggle with stress, especially when I'm juggling work, volunteering, and trying to stay connected with family. It's not always easy to prioritize self-care when there's so much going on, but I'm learning that even small things—like taking a few deep breaths or setting aside 10 minutes to stretch—can make a big difference. I think the key is being kind to myself and not getting too hard on the days when I don't do everything perfectly.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Joshua Lawson: In the past two years, I haven't had any major medical diagnoses or serious injuries, which I'm really grateful for. That said, there were a few moments where I had to slow down and take care of myself. One thing that stood out was a period of intense stress during the pandemic resurgence, when I was juggling more volunteer work and community organizing than ever before. I started experiencing some chronic fatigue and occasional chest tightness, which I initially brushed off as just being overworked. But after a few weeks of not feeling like myself, I made an appointment with my doctor. They ran some tests and found that I had mild anxiety-related symptoms, which made sense given the amount of emotional labor I was taking on. It was a wake-up call for me to prioritize my mental health more seriously. Since then, I've been more consistent with therapy, meditation, and setting boundaries around my work. I've also started paying more attention to how my body reacts to stress, and I've learned that even small changes—like taking a break from screens or going for a walk—can make a big difference. I think the biggest takeaway from that experience is that health isn't just about physical well-being; it's also about recognizing when you need to slow down and take care of yourself, even if it doesn't feel like the most productive thing to do at the time.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Joshua Lawson: Honestly, I haven't had any health issues that have really disrupted my ability to work or care for others, which I'm grateful for. But I think it's important to acknowledge that even small things can have a ripple effect. For example, during that time when I was dealing with anxiety-related symptoms, I found myself more easily overwhelmed by the demands of my work and volunteer commitments. It wasn't something that stopped me from showing up, but it did make me more prone to burnout and less able to give my full attention to the people I was trying to help. That experience taught me that my well-being isn't just a personal issue—it affects how I show up for others. I've since made a conscious effort to build in more rest and reflection, not just for myself, but also to model that for the kids I work with. I want them to know that it's okay to take a step back and take care of yourself, even if it feels counterintuitive when you're trying to make a difference.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Joshua Lawson: Over the past year, I've been feeling a mix of things—gratitude, growth, and a little bit of uncertainty. On one hand, I've been really proud of the work I've been doing in the community, especially with the kids at the community center. It's rewarding to see them grow and to know that I'm playing a small part in their journey. I've also been more intentional about taking care of myself, which has made a big difference in how I feel day to day. I've started setting clearer boundaries between my work and my personal time, which has helped me avoid burnout. But there's also been a lot of uncertainty, especially with the political climate and the ongoing issues in our neighborhood. I worry about the future, not just for myself but for the kids I work with and the people I care about. I feel like I'm in a place where I can make a difference, but I also know that change doesn't happen overnight. It's a balancing act—between staying hopeful and being realistic about the challenges we face. I think that's what keeps me going: the belief that even small actions can add up to something bigger, and that I'm part of something larger than myself.

Going through the interview questions from 16 to 20 made me reflect on how much my daily routines, health, and mental well-being are interconnected. It reminded me that even small changes—like setting aside time for self-reflection or journaling—can have a meaningful impact on how I show up for myself and others. It also made me think about how health isn't just about physical fitness or the absence of illness, but also about emotional resilience and the ability to recognize when I need to slow down. I've been learning that taking care of myself isn't a luxury, but a necessity, especially when I'm trying to make a difference in my community. These reflections have made me more aware of the importance of balance and self-compassion, and I'm trying to carry that awareness forward in everything I do.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Joshua Lawson: I think I've definitely struggled with anxiety at times, especially when I'm juggling a lot of responsibilities or feeling the weight of the issues in our community. It's not something I always talk about openly, but there have been moments when I felt overwhelmed by the pressure to do more, to be more, or to make a bigger impact than I think I can handle. I remember one particular stretch where I was working long hours at the community center, volunteering with multiple groups, and trying to stay connected with family and friends. I started feeling like I was constantly running on empty, and it was hard to tell where one responsibility ended and another began. I didn't want to burden anyone with my struggles, so I tried to push through, but it wasn't sustainable. That's when I realized I needed to be more honest about how I was feeling and ask for support when I needed it. I started seeing a counselor, and that made a huge difference. It helped me understand that it's okay to feel anxious or uncertain, and that taking care of my mental health isn't a sign of weakness—it's just as important as taking care of my physical health. I still have days where I feel the pressure, but I'm learning to recognize the signs and take steps to manage it before it gets too overwhelming.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Joshua Lawson: For my family, it's been a mix of support and concern, especially as I've been navigating this period of transition. My parents have always been there for me, but I think they've also been worried about the uncertainty of my path. They want the best for me, and they've seen me go through a lot in the past few years—whether it's the stress of community work, the challenges of gentrification in our neighborhood, or just the general pressure of figuring out what comes next. My sister, who's in college, has been a big source of encouragement. She's always pushing me to think about the long-term and to not be afraid of taking risks. My brother, on the other hand, is still in high school, and I think he looks up to me in a way that's both humbling and a little overwhelming. He's starting to explore his own interests, and I want to be a good example for him, even if I'm not entirely sure where I'm headed myself. Overall, I think they're proud of me, but they also want me to find stability. It's a delicate balance, but I'm grateful for their love and support—it's what keeps me going.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Joshua Lawson: For me, religion or spirituality hasn't played a central role in my life, though I've always been curious about the ways people find meaning and connection through faith. Growing up, my family wasn't particularly religious, and I never felt the need to fill that space with something formal. That said, I do think about the idea of purpose and how we connect to something bigger than ourselves—whether it's through community, activism, or just being there for the people around me. I've always felt that sense of responsibility to make a difference, and in a way, that's been my own kind of guiding force. I don't think of it as spirituality in the traditional sense, but I do believe in the power of empathy, kindness, and standing up for what's right. I think that's what keeps me going, even on the days when I feel uncertain or overwhelmed.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Joshua Lawson: I use social media mostly as a way to stay informed and connected to the causes I care about. I follow a lot of local activists, community organizers, and journalists who cover issues like housing, education, and racial justice. Instagram and Twitter have been especially useful for me because they allow me to see what's happening in real time and engage with people who are fighting for similar things. I also use Facebook to stay in touch with family and old friends, especially since I don't see them as often as I'd like. I try to be intentional about how I use these platforms—like limiting my time on them when I'm feeling overwhelmed or stressed. There's a lot of noise online, but I've learned to curate my feed so that it's mostly filled with voices that inspire me or challenge me to think differently. I also use social media to share my own work, whether it's articles I've written or updates about the community center I help run. It's a way to amplify the voices of the people I work with and to show that their stories matter. I think it's important to use these tools responsibly, especially when you're trying to make a difference in your community. They can be powerful, but they can also be exhausting if you're not careful.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Joshua Lawson: Honestly, I've found that social media can be a double-edged sword when it comes to support. On one hand, I've received emotional support from friends and even strangers who've shared similar struggles or who've been inspired by the work I do. There have been times when I posted about the challenges of community organizing or the stress of trying to make a difference, and people have reached out with encouragement or shared their own stories. That kind of connection is really meaningful. But I also know that relying too much on online support can feel superficial—like it's not the same as having someone physically there to listen or help. I think I've learned to use these platforms more as a tool for awareness and connection rather than a substitute for real, in-person support. When things get tough, I still turn to my family and close friends first. They're the ones who really understand what I'm going through, and I know I can count on them no matter what.

Going through the interview questions from 21 to 25 made me reflect deeply on my health, both physical and mental, and how it intertwines with the work I do in my community. It reminded me that even small changes—like setting aside time for self-reflection, journaling, or taking a walk—can have a meaningful impact on how I show up for myself and others. It also made me think about how health isn't just about physical fitness or the absence of illness, but also about emotional resilience and the ability to recognize when I need to slow down. I've been learning that taking care of myself isn't a luxury, but a necessity, especially when I'm trying to make a difference in my neighborhood. These reflections have made me more aware of the importance of balance and self-compassion, and I'm trying to carry that awareness forward in everything I do.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Joshua Lawson: In the past few months, I've noticed my stress levels have shifted—there's been a bit more of a ebb and flow, which I think is a good sign. I used to feel like I was constantly on edge, especially with everything going on in the neighborhood and the work I do. But lately, I've been more intentional about how I manage that stress. I've started incorporating more mindfulness into my routine, like short breathing exercises throughout the day or even just pausing for a few minutes when I feel overwhelmed. I've also been more open about my feelings with the people I work with, which has helped me feel less isolated. I think one of the biggest changes has been learning to set clearer boundaries—not just with my work, but also with my own expectations. I used to push myself to do more, to be more, but now I'm trying to focus on what's sustainable. It's not always easy, but I've come to realize that emotional resilience isn't about never feeling stressed or worried—it's about knowing how to respond when you do. I'm still learning, but I feel like I'm on the right path.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Joshua Lawson: Last month, my biggest expenses were rent, groceries, and transportation. I live in a small one-bedroom apartment near the community center, and the rent is about $1,200 a month. That's a chunk of my income, but I chose this location because it's close to where I work and volunteer, which makes it easier to stay connected to the neighborhood. Groceries usually come out to around $300, depending on what I'm cooking and how often I eat out. I try to cook most of my meals at home, but I do splurge on coffee or a meal out once in a while, especially on weekends when I meet up with friends. Transportation is another big one—since I don't own a car, I rely on public transit and sometimes ride-sharing apps, which adds up to about $150 a month. I also set aside money for utilities, internet, and a small amount for personal care and miscellaneous expenses. To make ends meet, I work part-time at the community center and do some freelance writing on the side. It's not always easy balancing everything, but I've learned to be pretty frugal and prioritize what's most important. I also try to save a little each month, even if it's just a small amount, just in case something unexpected comes up.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Joshua Lawson: To be honest, the $1,850 I spent last month is pretty close to what I usually spend each month, though it can vary a bit depending on the season or if I have to cover unexpected expenses. For example, during the colder months, my utility bills tend to go up a little because I use more heating, and I also spend a bit more on groceries if I'm hosting friends or buying ingredients for meals I can share with the community center. On the flip side, in the summer, I might spend a little less on heating but more on things like sunscreen or outdoor gear if I'm going on a walk or volunteering in the park. I've gotten pretty good at tracking my expenses using a simple spreadsheet, which helps me stay on top of things and make sure I'm not overspending. It's not always easy, especially when I'm trying to balance work, volunteering, and personal time, but I've learned that small adjustments—like cooking at home more or using public transit instead of ride-sharing—can make a big difference in the long run. I also try to set aside a little money each month for savings, even if it's just $50 or so, just in case something comes up. It's not a lot, but it gives me peace of mind knowing I'm not completely caught off guard if something unexpected happens.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Joshua Lawson: We rent our home. I live in a small one-bedroom apartment near the community center, and the rent is about $1,200 a month. I chose this location because it's close to where I work and volunteer, which makes it easier to stay connected to the neighborhood. I've been renting for a few years now, and while I know it's not the most stable situation, it's something I can manage with the part-time work I have and the freelance writing I do on the side. I've considered looking into buying a place eventually, but with the current housing market and the way things are changing in the city, I think I want to be more established in my work and personal life before making that kind of commitment. For now, renting feels like the right choice for me.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Joshua Lawson: Over the past year, my bills have definitely fluctuated, especially with the seasons and the different demands of my work. In the winter months, my utility bills went up because I was using more electricity for heating, and I also spent a bit more on groceries since I was cooking more at home and hosting friends for meals. I remember one month in January when I had to replace the heater in my apartment, which was an unexpected expense that added a few hundred dollars to my bill. That was stressful, but I was able to cover it with some savings I had set aside. In the summer, my electricity usage went down, but I started spending more on things like sunscreen, outdoor gear, and even a few ice cream treats to stay cool. I also noticed that during the holidays, my expenses went up a bit more because I was buying gifts for family and friends, even if it was just small things like cards or homemade cookies. Overall, I've learned to track my spending more closely and adjust my budget as needed. It's not always perfect, but I've gotten better at anticipating when things might change and planning for it, even if it's just a little at a time.

Going through the interview questions from 26 to 30 made me reflect on how my family's support and my approach to social media are deeply intertwined with my emotional well-being. Talking about my family reminded me of how much they've been there for me, even when I've been uncertain about my path. Their concern and encouragement have been a constant source of strength, and I realize now how important it is to communicate openly with them about my struggles and successes. It also made me think about how I use social media—not just as a tool for staying informed or connected, but also as a way to find support and share my voice. I've learned that while online connections can be meaningful, they're not a substitute for the real, in-person relationships that matter most. I'm trying to be more intentional about how I use these platforms, focusing on what inspires me and challenges me to think differently, while also remembering that my closest relationships are the ones that truly hold me up.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Joshua Lawson: I do save, though it's more of a habit than a formal plan. I set aside a small amount each month—usually around $50 to $75—into a savings account, even if it feels like not much. It's not about having a huge emergency fund right now, but more about building the habit of saving and giving myself a little financial cushion. I also try to save in other ways, like buying in bulk for groceries or using coupons when I can. I know it's not the same as having a big savings account, but it helps me feel more in control of my finances, especially when things get tight. I think the key for me is consistency—just putting something away regularly, even if it's not a lot. I also use part of my freelance income for savings, which gives me a little more flexibility. It's not perfect, but it's something I'm working on, and I know it's going to get easier as my income grows and my work becomes more stable.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Joshua Lawson: For me, saving has mostly been about building a sense of security, even if it's small. I haven't been saving specifically for a home yet—partly because I'm still figuring out what kind of path I want to take in the long run, and partly because the housing market here feels so unpredictable. I know a lot of people my age are thinking about buying, but I want to be more established in my work and personal life before making that kind of commitment. Instead, I've been focusing on saving for a rainy day, just in case something unexpected comes up. It's not a huge amount, but it gives me peace of mind knowing I have a little something set aside. I also try to save in other ways, like buying secondhand clothes or using public transit instead of ride-sharing when I can. It's not about luxury—it's about being prepared, even if it's just a little at a time. I think that's something I learned from my parents, who always emphasized the importance of being responsible with money, even when times were tough. I'm still learning, but I'm trying to carry that lesson forward in my own life.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Joshua Lawson: My occupation right now is part-time work at a local community center, where I help run after-school programs for kids and assist with administrative tasks. The most important part of my job is connecting with the youth in the neighborhood—listening to their stories, helping them with homework, and encouraging them to think critically about the world around them. I also organize workshops on civic engagement, which is something I'm really passionate about. It's not just about teaching them how to read or write; it's about showing them that their voices matter and that they have the power to make change. I've seen so many kids come through the program who are bright, curious, and full of potential, but they don't always have the support they need at home. That's why I try to be more than just a staff member—I want to be someone they can look up to, someone who believes in them even when they don't believe in themselves. It's not always easy, especially when I'm juggling my own responsibilities, but I think that's what makes it meaningful. I'm not sure what the future holds for me, but I know that as long as I can help even one kid feel seen and supported, I'm doing something right.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Joshua Lawson: I usually work around 20 to 25 hours a week, depending on the season and the needs of the community center. Some weeks are busier than others—especially during the school year, when the after-school programs are in full swing. I try to be flexible with my schedule so I can also volunteer with other organizations and stay involved in local activism. It's not a lot of hours, but it's enough to keep me connected to the work I care about without burning myself out. I've learned that balance is key, especially when you're trying to make a difference in your community while also taking care of yourself. I don't know what the future holds, but for now, this schedule feels sustainable and meaningful.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Joshua Lawson: Yes, I do have more than one job or source of income, though they're not always traditional. In addition to my part-time work at the community center, I also do some freelance writing on the side—mostly for local blogs, activist groups, or even social media campaigns that align with the causes I care about. It's not always steady work, and there are months where I don't get any freelance gigs, but it gives me the flexibility to explore different interests and support myself in a way that feels meaningful. I also volunteer with a few different organizations, like a food pantry and a youth mentorship group, which isn't paid work, but it's something I feel called to do. It's a bit of a juggling act, but I've learned to be intentional about how I spend my time. I think having multiple sources of income and involvement helps me stay grounded and reminds me that I don't have to follow one single path to make a difference. It's not always easy, but I'm grateful for the opportunities I have and the ways I can contribute to my community.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Joshua Lawson: In terms of income, my household made about $2,500 last month. That comes from my part-time job at the community center, which pays around $15 an hour, and the freelance writing I do on the side. I usually work about 20 to 25 hours a week at the center, so that's roughly $300 to $375 a week, and then the freelance work varies—sometimes I get a few gigs, sometimes not. I also have some small stipends from volunteer work, but those aren't consistent. It's not a lot, but it's enough to cover my basic needs and give me some flexibility. I've learned to be pretty careful with my money, especially since I don't have a lot of savings yet. I try to budget everything out, and I've gotten pretty good at tracking my expenses so I know where my money is going. It's not always easy, especially when I'm trying to balance work, volunteering, and personal time, but I've come to accept that this is where I am right now. I'm not in a rush to make more money—I'd rather focus on the work I care about and the people I'm trying to help.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Joshua Lawson: I've been at the community center for about two years now, and it's been a really formative experience for me. The benefits of the job aren't the traditional ones you might expect—there's no health insurance or paid vacation time, but what I get instead is something just as valuable: purpose. I know I'm not making a lot of money, but I feel like I'm contributing to something meaningful. The center offers some minimal benefits, like a small stipend for meals during long shifts and the ability to take unpaid leave if needed, which has been helpful in the past. What I appreciate most is the flexibility—it allows me to be present for my family, my community, and my own growth. I don't always have the luxury of time off, but when I do, it's because I've earned it through the work I do with the kids. I think that's one of the reasons I've stayed here—it's not just a job, it's a way of life that aligns with the values I hold most dear.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Joshua Lawson: My relationships at work are pretty much like family at this point. I've been working with the same group of people for almost two years now, and we've developed a really strong sense of trust and mutual support. My manager, Ms. Carter, is someone I really look up to—she's been through a lot in her own life and has this way of seeing potential in people even when they don't see it in themselves. She's never been overly strict or demanding; instead, she leads by example and always makes sure we feel valued for the work we do. As for my coworkers, we're all in this together. Some of them have been with the center longer than I have, and they've been great mentors, especially when it comes to understanding the nuances of working with kids in the neighborhood. We joke around, we support each other during tough times, and we all share this common goal of making a difference. It's not just a job—it's a community, and that's something I really appreciate.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Joshua Lawson: My work schedule is pretty flexible, which is one of the things I really appreciate about this job. Most of the time, I have a general idea of when I'll be working—like, if there's an after-school program running, I know I'll be there from 3 p.m. to 6 p.m., but there are also days where I can adjust my hours depending on what's needed. For example, if a workshop is scheduled earlier in the day or if someone needs coverage for a meeting, I can swap shifts with a coworker or come in a little earlier or stay a little later. That kind of flexibility is important for me, especially since I also volunteer with other organizations and need to stay connected with my family. It's not always perfect—there are times when I have to work late or on weekends, especially during the school year—but overall, I feel like I have a good balance. I think that flexibility is what makes this job feel more like a part of my life rather than just something I do to pay the bills.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Joshua Lawson: Overall, I feel like my financial situation is manageable, though it's definitely not without its challenges. I know I'm not making a lot of money, but I also know that I'm not spending beyond what I can afford. I've learned to be really intentional about every dollar I spend, and I think that's helped me stay afloat. There are days when I worry about the future—like, what happens if something unexpected comes up or if my part-time job changes? But I also remind myself that I'm not in this alone. I have a support system, both in my family and in the community, that helps me keep going. I don't see my financial situation as a limitation, but more as a reminder that I need to keep working hard, stay grounded, and keep doing the work that matters. I think as long as I'm making progress—whether it's through my job, my writing, or my activism—I'm in a good place. It's not about having a lot, but about having enough to keep moving forward and to keep helping others along the way.

Going through the interview questions from 36 to 40 made me reflect on how my financial stability, work schedule, and multiple income streams are all interconnected in shaping my daily life and sense of purpose. It also made me think about how my work schedule at the community center—being flexible yet unpredictable—allows me to stay involved in the work I care about while also giving me the freedom to support my family and community in other ways. I've come to accept that my income isn't always steady, but I've learned to make the most of what I have and find ways to contribute meaningfully, even if it's not always in the traditional sense. Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Joshua Lawson: Yes, both my parents worked for pay while I was growing up. My father worked full-time in business, and my mother was a teacher, which meant she had a more flexible schedule, especially during the school year. Even though my mother had some time off during summers and holidays, she was always involved in her work, and it was clear how much she cared about her students. My father, on the other hand, had a more traditional 9-to-5 job, but he was always supportive of my education and encouraged me to think critically about the world. Having both of them working meant that we had a stable home life, with both parents present and involved in my upbringing. I think that stability played a big role in shaping who I am today—knowing that my parents were working hard to give me opportunities, even if they weren't always perfect. It also made me more aware of the importance of education and the value of hard work, which is something I carry with me even now as I try to make a difference in my community.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Joshua Lawson: My father worked in business, primarily as a project manager for a mid-sized company that specialized in logistics and supply chain management. His most important activities involved coordinating between different departments, ensuring that projects stayed on schedule, and maintaining relationships with clients and vendors. He was pretty hands-on, always making sure that the team had what they needed to succeed. I remember him coming home tired but always making time to talk about his day, even if it was just a quick conversation over dinner. He taught me the value of responsibility and the importance of showing up, even when things got tough. My mother, on the other hand, was a high school teacher, and her most important duties revolved around creating lesson plans, grading assignments, and, most importantly, connecting with her students. She had a way of making even the most difficult subjects feel accessible, and she always encouraged her students to think critically and question everything. I remember watching her work late into the night, grading papers and preparing for the next day, and it made me realize how much dedication it took to be a teacher. Both of them had different jobs, but they shared a common trait—they were both deeply committed to their work and to making a difference, even in small ways. That's something I've carried with me, and it's one of the reasons I feel so strongly about the work I do now.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Joshua Lawson: My father worked for a mid-sized logistics company based in Philadelphia, and they specialized in managing supply chains for local and regional businesses. It was a pretty traditional business, but they had a strong focus on efficiency and customer satisfaction. My father was responsible for making sure that projects stayed on track, that deadlines were met, and that the team had the resources they needed to do their jobs. He wasn't just a manager in name—he was hands-on, often stepping in to help with problem-solving or negotiating with vendors when things got tricky. As for my mother, she worked at a public high school in the city, and she was part of a team of educators who were deeply committed to their students. She didn't just teach the material; she made sure her students felt seen and supported. She was always coming up with creative ways to engage them, whether it was through group projects, debates, or even bringing in guest speakers to talk about real-world issues. I think both of them were doing more than just their jobs—they were shaping the lives of the people around them, even if they didn't always realize it at the time.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Joshua Lawson: A few years from now, I hope I'm still in this neighborhood, still working with the kids at the community center, but maybe with more stability in my work and a clearer path forward. I don't know if I'll be in a full-time job or still doing freelance writing, but I hope I'm able to support myself in a way that allows me to keep doing the work I care about. I also hope I'm more established in my activism, maybe even helping to start or lead a local initiative that makes a real difference in our community. I want to be someone who others can look up to, just like my parents were for me. I hope I'm still learning, still growing, and still finding ways to give back. I don't think I'll ever be done figuring things out, but I hope I'm more confident in the choices I make and more sure of the impact I want to have. And I hope my family is proud of me, not just for what I accomplish, but for who I am and the kind of person I choose to be every day.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Joshua Lawson: What I value the most in my life is connection—whether it's with my family, my community, or the kids I work with at the community center. I think people are the most important thing, and I've always believed that the relationships we build are what give life meaning. I value the moments when I can truly listen to someone, when I can be there for them, and when I can help them feel seen. I also value growth, both for myself and for others. I don't think I've ever been someone who was content with staying the same—I always want to learn, to challenge myself, and to push forward, even when it's uncomfortable. I value the work I do because it allows me to be part of something bigger than myself, and I value the people who support me along the way, even when I don't always say it out loud. I think, at the end of the day, what I value most is the ability to make a difference, however small, in the lives of others.
